prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement, even though the basement would have been quieter. His job is mostly conference calls, so when he's on calls, the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him. This means the top floor is off-limits, and she can't do things like shower, do chores, or nap. She works from home too and handles most of the housework and kids. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, but if he went to the basement, they wouldn't bother him. He's upset she's not being quiet, but she thinks he's wrong for not choosing the basement.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband chose the bedroom for the view. But the wife is dealing with the consequences of his choice, like not being able to use the bathroom or shower. Since they have space in the basement, which is quieter, maybe he should have chosen there to avoid disrupting her. However, he's also working, so he might need a comfortable space. But the wife is handling most of the household and work, so her inability to function is a problem.

The key points: Did the husband make a reasonable choice that the wife should accommodate, or was the wife right to push back because his choice is causing her significant inconvenience? The wife isn't refusing to be quiet; she's saying she can't guarantee silence if he's in a space that's also their bedroom and top floor. The husband's job requires silence, but his choice of location is conflicting with her needs. The basement option would solve the problem. So maybe the husband is the one not being considerate by not choosing the basement. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
